alert.note: Alert for Dillon; Horry; Marion (South Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Wilmington (Northeastern South Carolina and Southeastern North Carolina - Wilmington)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued September 02 at 9:33AM EDT until September 05 at 2:00PM EDT by NWS Wilmington
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in North Carolina...South Carolina... Lumber River Near Lumberton affecting Robeson County. Northeast Cape Fear River Near Burgaw affecting Pender County. Lumber River 1 SE Nichols affecting Dillon, Marion and Horry Counties. Little Pee Dee River At Galivants Ferry affecting Marion and Horry Counties. ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in South Carolina... Waccamaw River At Conway affecting Horry County. Black River At Kingstree affecting Williamsburg County. For the Northeast Cape Fear River...including Burgaw...Moderate flooding is forecast. For the Lumber River...including Nichols, Pembroke, Lumberton Usgs Gage, Maxton, Lumberton, Boardman...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Little Pee Dee River...including Galivants Ferry...Moderate flooding is forecast. For the Waccamaw River...including Aiw At old Hwy 544 At Socastee, Conway, Above Conway, Freeland, Longs...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Black River...including Kingstree...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL EARLY TUESDAY AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Lumber River 1 se Nichols. * WHEN...Until early Tuesday afternoon. * IMPACTS...At 21.0 feet, Flooding worsens along River Road and begins along Drowning Creek Drive. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:00 AM EDT Saturday the stage was 20.6 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 20.8 feet this evening. It will then fall below flood stage early Tuesday morning. - Flood stage is 20.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Additional information is available at water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=ilm . The next statement will be issued by late tonight.
